title: 108_s2772
content: The Act may be cited as the "Space Commercial Human Ascent Serving Expeditions Act" or the "Space CHASE Act". The Congress finds that opening space to American people and their private enterprises should guide Federal space investments. Private industry is developing commercial launch vehicles for human space travel, which will stimulate the commercial space transportation industry. Space transportation is risky, and regulation of commercial human space flight is crucial for public interest. The Congress finds that regulation of commercial human space flight is crucial for public interest. In amending Section 70101 of title 49, United States Code, subsection (a)(3) includes "human space flight," and subsection (a)(4) updates language regarding satellite capabilities. Section 70102 is also amended to redefine "crew" as employees of licensees or contractors in commercial space flight. The text chunk discusses amendments to language regarding crew, payload, and space flight participants in relation to commercial space flight activities. The text chunk outlines amendments related to crew, payload, and space flight participants for commercial space flight activities, including defining terms like "permit" and "space flight participant." The text chunk introduces new definitions for "suborbital rocket" and "suborbital trajectory" in relation to commercial space flight activities. The text chunk amends Section 70103(a) of title 49, United States Code, to include the Associate Administrator for Commercial Space Transportation and ensure sufficient personnel from the Federal Aviation Administration for commercial human space flight activities. Section 70103 of title 49, United States Code is amended to include space flight participants in private sector activities. Section 70104 is amended to clarify license and permit requirements for launch and reentry sites. The Secretary of Transportation shall not impose additional requirements for licenses or permits issued under this chapter, including for space flight activities. Section 70105 of title 49, United States Code, is amended to update licensing requirements and introduce a new subsection for experimental permits under the Secretary of Transportation. The Secretary of Transportation will issue an experimental permit within 90 days if the applicant complies with regulations. Any pending issues will be communicated within 60 days. Notifications will be sent to relevant committees within 15 days of any occurrence. The Secretary may establish safety procedures for commercial space activities and issue permits for reusable suborbital rockets for research and development purposes. The Secretary will use authority to encourage industry development and must notify committees within 15 days of any permit issues. Permits issued for reusable suborbital rockets authorize unlimited launches and reentries for a specific rocket design, with specified allowable modifications. Permits are not transferable and become invalid once a license is issued for the same rocket design. The permits for reusable suborbital rockets allow unlimited launches and reentries for a specific rocket design, with specified allowable modifications. Permits are not transferable and become invalid once a license is issued for the same rocket design. The issuance of a permit is considered licensing for the purposes of various sections in the chapter. Section 70105 of title 49, United States Code, is amended to include additional requirements for licenses or permits for launch or reentry vehicles, ensuring that human beings onboard have the necessary authorization. Section 70105 of title 49, United States Code, now includes requirements for licenses or permits for launch or reentry vehicles with human crew members. The crew must meet specified training and medical standards, comply with US laws, and space flight participants must adhere to regulations. The holder of the license or permit must inform the space flight participant about risks and obtain written consent. Compliance with US laws related to launching or reentering a space flight participant is required. Section 70106(a) of title 49, United States Code, is amended to include crew training sites for launch vehicle assembly and reentry. Section 70110(a)(1) is amended to update references, and Section 70112(b)(1) is amended to include space flight participants in waiver requirements. Section 70112(b)(2) of title 49, United States Code, is amended to include crew and space flight participants in certain provisions. Section 70113(a)(1) is amended to provide protection but not against space flight participants. Section 70113(f) is amended to extend the deadline to December 31, 2007. Section 70115(b)(1)(D)(i) is amended to include crew training sites. Section 70119 of title 49, United States Code, is amended to allocate $11,776,000 for fiscal years 2005, 2006, and 2007. Section 70120 is amended to require the Secretary to publish proposed regulations within 12 months and issue final regulations within 18 months after the enactment of the Commercial Space Launch Amendments Act of 2004. The Secretary must issue final regulations within 18 months of the enactment of the Commercial Space Launch Amendments Act of 2004. Licenses and permits for launch or reentry of vehicles with humans on board can be issued before regulations are finalized. Guidelines will be provided until regulations are in place, but no licenses or permits can be issued three years after the Act's enactment without final regulations. The Secretary of Transportation will conduct a study on gradually eliminating the liability risk sharing regime for commercial space transportation in the US. The study will assess methods to eliminate the regime by 2008 or soon after, including incremental approaches. Additionally, a technical amendment repeals Section 102(c) of the Commercial Space Act of 1998.
